Projects
CIID Summer School
menu

How might we improve the living qualities of human beings by acheiving sustainable development goals (SDG) putforth by UN

Explore
Overview

I took a little break from my professional career to attend summer school conducted by the Copenhagen Institute of Interaction Design (CIID) in India for 3 weeks. It was a whole new experience as I moved away from my routine work of building products only for consumers. Here I worked on projects that focussed on natural disaster rehabilitation, environmental pollution and inclusive child care mechanisms. I learnt about how design can create socially innovative solutions and impact millions of lives for a better cause.

Duration Dec 7 2018 - Dec 21 2018 (3 Weeks)
Domain Non Profitable Service Sector
Done as Summer School Projects

During the entire course of study, double diamond approach was emphasized to follow in every projects

5 Days
Project 1
The Communion

The purpose of this project is to identify the major regrowth areas after the flood had affected the Kerala State in India. The loss of the state have been humongous and there is need for bringing back things to stable. There are lot of people who were affected both physically and mentally. We found that they need a lot of support to bring back to their daily livelihood. The study concentrated on the areas where we can provide better service for the victims such that they have a smooth transition during the course of the rehabilitation.

Class Title Intro to Service Design
Team Size 6 Members
SDG Goal Goal 13: Climate Action
Service Design Class - Batch Members

We began with the background study to understand the impacts the Kerala floods had created. Then we conducted user interviews among the victims, government officials and NGOs who were involved in the recovery process. We also conducted online surveys to learn more about the key challeneged that the people have faced. Then we clustered and formed themes based on the data we collected from the interviews and surveys.

Based on the severity of damage to each individuals, we drew out the support needed at each phase of rehabilitation

Insights we got from the analysis were the loss of mental & financial support post-disaster. And also improper organization since there is a need for “act immediately”

Our team brainstormed both lateral and logical idea in a rapid 20 minutes session

Following are some of the conceptual sketches we came up wtith. Then everyone reviewed reviewed each of these concepts and gave their feedback. Based on that, we finalised one conceptual service design for post-flood rehabilitation

One of the service design conceptual model is Communion

Description Building a temporary community among the people living in various relief camps to share their emotions and skill sets in a productive way. In this model, revenue is generated by the victim which is immediately used by the government and later provided to the individuals once they leave the relief campaign
Value for Citizen Avoid Loneliness; Share Emotions; Spend time in a productive way; Connectivity with new people; Generate Revenue
Value for Government Rehabilitation made easy; Sustainable Development & Job Opportunities; Pestering from the people in the relief camp will be reduced; New/Increased Volunteers; Increased Involvement
2 Days
Project 2
Lil Chefs

Children in Child Care Institutions are excluded from society for various reasons. However, they are offended with many facilities inside their institution itself. We visited a Child Care Institution in Kerala to explore the situation they are facing. We found that Children in that institution are satisfied with all their primary needs except “food”. The study concentrated primarily on providing a better standard of food to satisfy the children and provide a healthy life.

Class Title Design for Inclusion
Team Size 3 Members
SDG Goal Goal 10: Reduced Inequality
Intro to Inclusive Design Class - Batch Members

We spent half a day in this child care institution gaining insights from children who are put in here for more than 6 years. We conducted guerrilla research and also conducted in-depth interviews with a few students. In order to conduct interview in a fun and not in boring way, we used few research tools and conducted activities to make sure they are engaged throughout the interview.

Insights we got from the analysis was food provided by the instituion lack taste, variety, and hygiene. So the students prefer outside food more than that they are providing in the institution

Conceptual model we proposed is Lil Chefs

Description Since household activities like cleaning, gardening and similar activities are taken care children themselves, building a "do it yourself" concept for the children in the cooking department will create transparency and will help them in understanding their requirements
Value for Citizen Have a chance to make the quality of food better by themselves. Have a chance to be inspired by a cooking activity. Feel the sense of accomplishment
Value for Government Transfer budget from labor to ingredients. Reduce children’s unsatisfactory. Grow sense of self-initiative
Exisiting model
Proposed model
Story Board
2 Days
Project 3
Put Tickets

Since the ticketing system for mass transportation in Kerala (a province in India) is mostly paper-based, littering of tickets are always been a huge problem in various transportation terminals like bus terminals, railway station and ferry boat terminals. However, when our team examined closely in various terminals, we found that ferry terminals are one which got affected most because of its difficulty in cleaning since most of the litters are being thrown into the water. We aim to solve this problem to contribute our little part to the United Nation’s one of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): Sustainable Cities and Communities.

Class Title Design for Behavior and it's Impacts
Team Size 4 Members
SDG Goal Goal 14: Life Below Water Goal 6: Clean Water and Sanitation
Designing for Behaviors and it's Impacts - Batch Members

We visited Vypin Ferry Terminal, one the densely packed terminals in Kerala to understand the behavior of the people who are frequently using that terminal and identified the reason behind the littering. To find out the right intervention point, we tracked down the journey of the ticket from the hands of ticket counter to the disposal into the water.

Identifying the Behavioral Biases

It is actually a good process since the ticket is collected at a single point instead of giving the passengers, the freedom to throw wherever they want. But the problem is with the ticket collector. When we interviewed their team, they told that there is no dustbin or any other similar medium for disposal. So that, they have no other options, but to throw into the water. Since the same custom is followed for a quite long period, all other newly joined ticket collectors are also the same process

Solution we proposed is Put Tickets

Looking back at
The Reflections from
Service Design Class

Learnt new user research tools which were effective during the discovery phase. Understood how to address the real-time problem by designing a service. Learnt the importance of including every stakeholder in the chain of service while designing because every interaction the user makes will have a ripple effect on each of these stakeholders.

Design for Inclusion Class

Start from thinking about “when do I feel a sense of exclusion?”. Inclusive design is not an outcome, but a process. Our proposal will give new inspiration to atleast some children.

Design of Behaviors and it's Impacts Class

Learnt different behavioral biases such as time inconsistency biases, social biases, decision-making biases and probability belief biases. Consider the entire job aspects. In our case, we considered other jobs done by the ticket collector in the boat apart from collecting tickets. While doing the behavioral diagnosis, considering the unnoticed behavior is of equal importance to that of a noticed one. Make sure your solutions don’t add new hassle factors. Try to embed them into existing behaviors.

Overall

It was one of the best learning experiences in my life as each project comprised of people from educational background from different countries with different mindsets. Each people attended different workshops and contributed their previous learnings in their next workshop which I found very valuable. Since this summer school was attended during my employment, it was a whole new experience as I moved away from my routine work of building products only for consumers. This made me realize that design is the best method to solve problems that we haven’t faced in our normal life.
